Nouns are the words we use to indicate people, animals, things, processes or abstract relations, e.g.: nieida 'girl', Káre 'Káre (a name)', beavdi 'table', ráhkisvuohta 'love', dávda 'illness', Norga 'Norway'.

section.title: Different stems
section.p: In Sami nouns are declined, that is, they take different forms to indicate what they are used for in a given sentence. The declension forms of nouns vary according to the number of syllables in the final foot of a word. The term foot, perhaps familiar from the study of poetry, is a group of syllables in which the first syllable has stress. In the examples below, syllables are separated with "-", and feet are enclosed in parentheses "()". Stress is marked with a single apostrophe "'" preceding the syllable.

ul.li: gussa 'cow' ('gus-sa) consists of two syllables and one foot.
sámegiella 'Sami language' ('sá-me)('giel-la) consists of four syllables and two feet.
fatnasa 'boat' ('fa-tna-sa) consists of three syllables and one foot.
vilbealle 'male cousin' ('vil)('beal-le) consists of three syllables and two feet.

section.p: Bisyllabic nouns are nouns that have two syllables in the final foot in the nominative plural.

ul.li: gussa - gusat ('gu-sat) consists of two syllables and one foot.
vilbealle - vilbealit ('vil)('bea-lit) consists of three syllables and two feet.
sámegiella - sámegielat ('sá-me)('gie-lat) consists of four syllables and two feet.
gonagas - gonagasat 'king' ('go-na)('ga-sat) consists of four syllables and two feet.
gonagasbárdni - gonagasbártnit 'prince' ('go-na-gas)('bárt-nit) consists of five syllables and two feet.

section.p: These nouns are strong grade in the nominative singular, and weak grade in the plural.
Trisyllabic nouns have three syllables in the final foot in the nominative plural.

ul.li: rieban - riebanat 'fox' ('rie-ba-nat) has three syllables and one foot.
nisu - nissonat 'woman' ('nis-so-nat) has three syllables and one foot.
ruksesrieban - ruksesriebanat 'red fox' ('ruk-ses)('rie-ba-nat) has five syllables and two feet.

section.p: The nominative singular and essive are weak-grade forms, the other forms are strong-grade, but not all trisyllabic nouns are subject to gradation.
Contracted nouns have two syllables in the final foot in both the singular and the plural. The noun is weak-grade in the nominative singular and strong or extra strong-grade in the in the plural.

ul.li: boazu - bohccot 'reindeer' ('bohc-cot) has two syllables and one foot.
bálggis - bálgát 'path' ('bál-gát) has two syllables and one foot.
vuovdebálggis - vuovdebálgát 'forest path' ('vuov-de)('bál-gát) has four syllables and two feet.
olmmái - olbmát 'husband, companion' ('olb-mát) has two syllables and one foot.

section.title: Diphthong simplification
section.p: The diphthong in the first syllable of a foot can be affected by the vowel in the second syllable. The diphthong becomes a monophthong (a simple vowel) when the vowel in the second syllable is:

ul.li: -ii- , e.g. gihtii (giehta) 'hand; arm'
-ui- , but only in the illative singular, e.g. vissui (viessu) 'house'
-o- , e.g. bohccot (boazu) 'reindeer'

section.p: In contracted nouns that end in "-u", diphthong simplification occurs in all cases, except for the nominative singular and the essive.

section.title: Consonant gradation
section.p: Gradation usually occurs in the consonant cluster between the first and second syllable in the final foot, e.g. sámegiella - sámegiela 'the Sami language'. This alternation is called gradation. We have, e.g. strong-grade forms in the nominative singular in bisyllabic nouns, and in the nominative plural iin trisyllabic nouns. The weak-grade form, it will be noted, is what occurs for example in the nominative plural in bisyllabic nouns, or in the nominative singular in trisyllabic nouns.

Here are some examples of gradation - strong-grade forms on the left, weak-grade forms on the right. Please, note that, when the letter "-i-" follows a vowel, it, in fact, indicates a consonant [-j-], and for this reason it is part of the consonant cluster:

ul.li: mánná - mánát 'child', lávvu - lávut 'lavvu', viessu - viesut, guolli - guolit
láibi - láibbit, báidi - báiddit, lávlagat - lávlla
oabbá - oappát, stággu - stákkut,
beatnagat - beana, vuopmi - vuomit
uksa - uvssat, gákti - gávttit
gáhkku - gáhku, áhčči - áhčit

section.p: Bisyllabic nouns can also end in consonants in the nominative singular, for example, words such as gonagas 'king', lávvardat 'Saturday'. In the declension of these words you will note an extra syllable, and the word will be broken into two feet: ('go-na)('ga-sa) 'of the king'. Since the final foot is now bisyllabic, it is open to consonant gradation. The strong grade will occur in the illative singular and the essive. Here are some examples with the nominative singular, nominative plura and the illative singular:

ul.li: gonagas - gonagasat - gonagassii 'king'
lávvardat - lávvardagat - lávvardahkii 'Saturday'
ofelaš - ofelaččat - ofelažžii
borramuš - borramušat - borramuššii 'food'

section.p: You can read more about consonant gradation here

section.title: Other consonant gradation
section.p: Some nouns end in consonants in the nominative singular. In North Sami, there\ are limitations as to which consonants can occur in word-final position, and this is where we can observe special types of consonant-gradation variation between the nominative singular and the other cases. The consonants that can occur in word-final position are: "t", "s", "š", "l", "r" and "n". Here are some examples of consonant gradation in trisyllabic nouns and the word "olmmoš" 'person':

ul.li: t > h, e.g. rievssat - rievssaha 'ptarmigan'
t > d, e.g. eamit - eamida 'lady of the house, hostess'
t > g, e.g. rusttet - rusttega 'equipment'
t > b, e.g. ustit - ustiba 'friend'
n > m, e.g. goaskin - goaskima 'eagle'
š > ž, e.g. cizáš - cizáža 'little bird', olmmoš - olmmožin 'person'

section.p: Note that "š" and "n" are not always subject to consonant gradation: bearaš - bearraša 'family', gearpmaš - gearbmaša 'snake', čálán - čálána 'writer', suohpan - suohpana 'reindeer herder's lassoo'.
Bisyllabic nouns that end in consonants undergo similar variation:

ul.li: t > g, e.g. sihkaldat - sihkaldaga 'towel'
š > čč, e.g. sápmelaš - sápmelačča 'Sami person'

section.p: Bisyllabic nouns also undergo consonant gradation in these consonants, read more about this variation here.
Some trisyllabic nouns that end in a vowel in the nominative singular also acquire and extra consonant in the other forms:

ul.li: _ > g, e.g. beana - beatnaga 'dog', gáma - gápmaga 'shoe'
_ > m, e.g. ađa - ađđama 'marrow', gietkka - gietkama 'cradle'

section.p: Contracted nouns that end in "-i" undergo a spelling change in the literary language with the "i" of the nominative singular form changing to "j" in the essive.

ul.li: i > j, e.g. olmmái - olmmájin, almmái - almmájin 'man, husband'

section.title: Cases
section.p: are declension forms that mark which function a noun phrase head has in a sentence. A noun phrase head is typically a noun or pronoun but it can also be and adjective or a numeral. In North Sami there are seven cases.

section.title: The nominative
section.p: is the case give as the base form (presentational form) of a noun phrase head. It is the case used to mark the subject and the subject complement or predicative. The ending "-t" is used to mark the nominative plural.
Bisyllabic nouns are strong-grade in the singular and weak-grade in the plural: Min 'gussa' lea návehis. (Our cow is in the cowshed.) Min 'gusat' leat návehis. (Our cows are in the cowshed.)

Trisyllabic nouns are weak-grade in the singular and strong-grade in the plural, e.g. Čoahkkimis lea dušše okta 'nisu'. (There is only one lady at the meeting.) Čoahkkimis leat ollu 'nissonat'. (There are a lot of women at the meeting.)

Contracted nouns are weak-grade in the singular and strong or extra strong-grade in the plural. In the plural there is also diphthong simplification, e.g. Šiljus lea 'boazu'. (There is a reindeer [tethered] in the yard.) Duoddaris leat ollu 'bohccot'. (There are a lot of reindeer in the fells.)

section.title: The accusative
section.p: is the case used to indicate the object, e.g. Mun oasttán 'gusa'. (I'm going to buy a cow.) In the plural the accusative marker is "-id".

Bisyllabic nouns are weak-grade in both the singular and the plural. Nouns that end in "-i" undergo diphthong simplification in the plural: Mun oasttán 'gusa'/'gusaid'. (gussa) (I am going to buy a cow / cows). Mun čorgen 'goađi'/'gođiid'. (goahti) (I am going to clean the goahti / goahtis.)
Trisyllabic nouns are strong-grade, and in the singular they end in "-a": Mun dovddan 'nissona'/'nissoniid'. (nisu). (I know a woman / women.)
Contracted nouns are strong or extra strong-grade, and they also have diphthong simplification: Gal mun oainnán 'bohcco'/'bohccuid'. (boazu) (I see a reindeer /reindeer.)
In North Sami, the accusative and genitive forms are identical.

section.title: The genitive
section.p: is the case used to mark the possessor: 'nissona' lávka (the woman's purse), 'skuvlla' njuolggadusat (school rules). The genitive is also used in other contexts, e.g. to mark the complement of postpositions and prepositions: 'sullo' lahka (near the island). The genitive is also used in combination with expressions with cardinal numerals when the number is larger than "1": guokte 'nieidda' ja golbma 'bártni' (two girls and three boys). The genitive plural is marked with "-id".

Bisyllabic nouns are weak-grade in both the singular and the plural. Nouns that end in "-i" undergo diphthong simplification in the plural: Dat lea 'gusa'/'gusaid' biebmu. (gussa) (That is cow's/cows' feed.) Dat leat 'goađi'/'gođiid' duohken. (goahti) (They are behind the goahti.)
Trisyllabic nouns are strong-grade, and in the singular they end in "-a": Dat lea 'nissona'/'nissoniid' lávka. (nisu) (That is the woman's/ women's purse.)

Contracted nouns are strong or extra strong-grade, and they are subject to diphthong simplification: Mun bivden guoli 'sullo'/'sulluid' davábealde. (suolu) (I caught a fish on the north side of the island/islands.)
In North Sami, the accusative and genitive forms are identical.

section.title: The illative
section.p: is the case that indicates motion toward or into something. The illative can also be used to indicate the recipient: Mun manan 'skuvlii'. (I'm going to school.) - Sii mannet 'skuvllaide'. (They are going to the schools.) Son attii 'mánnái' girjji. (He/She gave the child a book.) Mánná bijai girjji 'hildui'. (The child put the book on the shelf.) There are also illative verbs, that is verbs that require a noun in the illative. The verbs liikot 'to like' and álgit 'to start' are examples of some typical illative verbs: Son álgá 'skuvlii'. (He/She is starting school.) Mun liikon 'eadnái'. (I like mom.) Read more about illative verbs here.

Bisyllabic nouns are strong-grade, the vowel in the second syllable changes and the ending "-i" is added: láibái (láibi) 'into the bread', gussii (gussa) 'to the cow', reŋkui (reŋko) '', báŋkui (báŋku) 'into/to the bank'.
Nouns ending in "-u" and "-a" undergo diphthong simplification in the singular: merrii (mearra) 'into the sea', vissui (viessu) 'into the house'.
Trisyllabic nouns are strong-grade and end in "-ii": nissonii (nisu) 'to the woman'.
Contracted nouns are strong or extra strong-grade and take the ending "-i". There is also diphthong simplification: bohccui (boazu) 'to the reindeer', sullui (suolu) 'to the island'.
In the plural the ending is "-ide": láibbiide 'into the loaves', bohccuide 'to the reindeer' og ulikestavelsessubstantiv får '-iidda': nissoniidda 'to the women'.
Kontrakte substantiv og likestavelsessubstantiv som slutter på -i får diftongforenkling: gođiide (goahti) 'to the goahtis', sulluide (suolu) 'to the islands'.

section.title: The locative
section.p: is the case that is used to indicate the notions in/at or from a place. The locative can also indicate the giver or where something comes from: Mánát leat 'skuvllas'. (The children are at school.) Mánát bohtet 'skuvllas'. (The children are coming from school.) Mun ožžon 'áhčis' niibbi. (I got a knife from dad.) Mii gulaimet 'radios' ođđasiid. (We heard the news on the radio.) The locative can also be used in "have" constructions: 'Nieiddas' leat ollu girjjit. (The girl has lots of books.) There are also locative verbs. These are verbs that require a noun in the locative case. The verbs "beroštit" 'to be interested in', "ballat" 'to be afraid of' and "heaitit" 'to quit': Mun beroštan 'dus'. (I'm interested in your well-being.) Bárdni heittii 'skuvllas'. (The boy quit school.) Mánát balle 'beatnagis'. (The children were afraid of the dog.) Read more about locative verbs here.

In the singular the ending is "-s". Bisyllabic nouns are weak-grade: gusas (gussa) 'the cow [has]', and trisyllabic nouns are strong-grade: nissonis (nisu) 'the woman [has]'. Contracted nouns are strong or extra strong-grade and undergo diphthong simplification: bohccos (boazu) 'the reindeer [has]'.

In the plural the ending is "-in". Contracted nouns and bisyllabic nouns ending in "-i" undergo diphthong simplification: gusain 'the cows [have]', gođiin 'in the goahtis', nissoniin 'the women [have]', bohccuin 'the reindeer have'.

section.title: The comitative
section.p: is the case that often indicates the notion "with": Mun čuohpan láibbi 'niibbiin'. (I'm cutting the bread with a knife.) Mun hupmen 'vieljain' ikte. (I spoke with [my] brother yesterday.) There are also comitative verbs.

In the singular the ending is "-in". Bisyllabic nouns are weak-grade, and words ending in "-i" undergo diphthong simplification gusain (gussa) 'with the cow', gođiin (goahti) 'with the goahti', trisyllabic nouns are strong-grade, nissoniin (nisu) 'with the woman', and contracted nouns are strong or extra strong-grade with diphthong simplification: bohccuin (boazu) 'with the reindeer [pl.]', sulluin (suolu) 'with an island [postmodifier]'.

The plural ending is "-iguin". Contracted nouns and bisyllabic nouns ending in "-i" undergo diphthong simplification: niibbiiguin 'with knives', etniiguin 'with mothers', nissoniiguin 'with women', bohccuiguin 'with reindeer [pl.]'.

section.title: The essive
section.p: is the case that provides the notion "like, as, for". The essive can also indicate "when" or "under what conditions" something happens, or what something is called (it also marks object complement).
Viessu geavahuvvo 'skuvlan'. (The house is used as/for a school.)
'Arvin' in gille mannat oaggut. (When it rains, I don't like to go fishing.)
'Nuorran' mun lohken ollu divttaid. (When I was young, I read a lot of poems.
Mii gohčodit beatnaga 'Čáhppen'. (We call the dog Čáhppe.)
'Ovdamearkan' sáhttá atnit Guovdageainnu ja Kárášjoga. (You can use Kautokeino and Karasjok as examples.).
Mun lean šaddan 'siessán'. (I have become an aunt.)

The ending "-n" is added directly to the nominative singular form of bisyllabic nouns with word-final vowels. There is no distinction made between singular and plural. Trisyllabic nouns and contracted nouns ending in a consonant in the nominative singular take the ending "-in" added to the nominative singular: mális - málisin 'for a meal', olmmái - olmmájin 'as a man/husband'. Bisyllabic nouns that end in a consonant are marked with "-an" after the consonant. The consonants should be strong-grade in the essive: gonagas - gonagassan 'as a king', sihkaldat - sihkaldahkan 'for a towel'.
